results.title: Bitter Surrender
results.brief_description: A documentary about an overlooked aspect of adoption, the experience of mothers who have surrendered or given up their children. Through the personal accounts of five women, it explores and exposes what the legally enforced secrecy surrounding adoption hides, that the majority of women who relinquish their children face seemingly unresolvable shame and grief.

results.title: Bitter Rice
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Graham Chase and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is a documentary examining the political struggle in the Philippines. It focuses on the life and exploits of Bernabe Buscayno, alias Kommanda Dante, legendary figure, founder of the New People’s Army, and long time defender of the people. This gripping film looks at Dante’s recent efforts to bring about political and economic change by establishing the People’s Livelihood Foundation - an open co-operative for rice farmers in Capas, which represents the people’s struggle to earn from their land … so far the struggle has been peaceful.

results.title: Bitter paradise: The Sellout of East Timor
results.brief_description: Prior to Indonesian invasion and subsequent occupation, Portugese East Timor was a country far removed from external influences. Anthropologists from the west visted the country as an example of a preserved culture. Canadian tourist and photographer, Elaine Briere, visited in 1974; her photos remain as some of the only documents that attest to the peaceful existence of the country prior to invasion. Briere presents a harsh case against Western society, in particular Canada, and their complicity in allowing the military elite of the Suharto government to invade East Timor. A move that was motivated by a desire to control raw material and exploit new markets. Briere’s photographs and the testimonies provided by East Timorese who survived to tell of the atrocities that occurred are compiled as a photo documentary of the solidarity movement. More than anything, this documentary is a moving tribute to a country with a determination to maintain their independence and culture from assimilation, as well as promoting awareness of the East Timor occupation. Warning: This documentary contains scenes which may offend some viewers.

results.title: Bits and pieces
results.creator_credit: Leisl Hillhouse, Emerald Films and Simon Klaebe
results.brief_description: A seemingly innocent “neat freak” (Jeremy Callaghan) patiently, yet swiftly cleans his house, under the watchful eye of a dog who may or may not be the cause of the proliferation of waste. As the milkman arrives to replenish the bottles, the plot takes an unexpected twist.

results.title: Bits and bytes. Parts 1-12
results.creator_credit: Time-Life Video, TV Ontario, Denise Boiteau, David Stansfield and Stuart Beecroft
results.brief_description: Part 1. ‘Getting started’. Part 2. “Ready made programs’. Part 3. ‘How programs work’. Part 4. ‘Storing information’. Part 5. ‘Communication between computers’. Part 6.’Computer languages’. Part 7. ‘Computer assisted instruction’. Part 8. ‘Learning objectives’. Part 9. ‘Computer Graphics’. Part 10 ‘Computer music’. Part 11. ‘Computers at work’. Part 12 ‘What next’. Based on the Apple II series computer, and IBM, there are sound basic explanations about basic computer functions and programs.

results.title: BIT Plane
results.brief_description:
The Bitplane video captures an aero-portrait of a richly mythologised territory - the Silicon Valley in California, home to the largest concentration of wealth in California since the Gold Rush. The Bitplane’s mission takes it deep into the heart of the Valley, to view the source and progress of the Information Age. Due to its tiny dimensions, the Bitplane is able to enter territory inaccessible to other aircraft.

One of the issues the Bitplane engages with on this reconnaissance flight is the threat of the camera to information space. Cameras are not permitted into the corporate research parks in teh Valley, according to the logic that visitors could steal intellectual property by taking photographs. This reveals an assumption that information is something you can photograph, a thing - not the product of a community or expertise or a social network of shared discourse but something you could steal with a camera.

From the Artist Statement provided for PROOF exhibition, Dec 2004.

results.title: Bismarck: Germany from blood and iron
results.creator_credit: Malcolm B. Heyworth, John irvin, Learning Corporation of America and Chatsworth Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Western Civilization”.
Nationalism is a major force in modern history, and national unity has often been forged in war. This film traces the step-by-step creation of modern Germany and suggests its implications for the rest of the world. In 1815 there were thirty-nine separate German-speaking states in a confederation under Austrian leadership. By 1871 a united German nation was born, led by the northern state of Prussia and the man who was to be its first Chancellor - Otto Von Bismarck. Relaxing with two American friends, the architect of the new Germany recollects the steps which led up to unification, which is told in a series of flashbacks. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Biscuits by the million
results.creator_credit: Roy A. Driver and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: This is story of biscuit manufacture in a modern factory of the 50’s. The flour, sugar and milk that forms the basic dough of every biscuit is mixed, kneaded, rolled, stretched and stamped, and ready for final baking in a long oven through which biscuits pass continuously. When cooled they are packed in tins, the only operation carried out by hand. Most of the biscuits are consumed locally, although a percentage are exported to other parts of the world.

results.title: Bischoff's Mountain: an epitaph
results.brief_description: A montage of stills, showing a now disused and decaying tin mine on Bischoff’s Mountain in Tasmania. Also shows Waratah one of Tasmania’s ghost towns. The visuals are accompanied with an overlay of industrial noises and male voices - suggestive of the previous industrial life of the town.

results.title: Birthdays
results.creator_credit: Michael Rogers, Linda Rawlings and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Australians, from all ages, from all backgrounds, discuss mythologies and stories connected with birth, mothering and pregnancy. The video utilises the imagery of water to represent the foetal world of the womb. By contrasting stories of pain and joy; accounts from mothers and accounts from adults who have undergone re-birthing; and by contrasting different cultural experiences of birth, “Birthdays” ultimately is a testament to the crucial role, ideas surrounding birth and mothering have on forming individual and cultural identity.
